figures.description:
The image is a screenshot of a computer screen displaying an applications interface with various system information sections titled differently: "Applications," "Big data enterprise." "Blogs," "Cloud," and others. Each section has different text and icons suggesting functionality and options. On the left side, there's a vertical menu listing entries such as "Applications," "Big data enterprise.," "Blogs," "Digital enterprise strategy," "Big data strategy," "Analytics & dashboards," "Cloud," "Hyper ledger." Each menu item leads to different applications or services.

The main content of the screen consists of a colorful flowchart with various shapes and lines connecting them, representing different paths for processes or operations within a networked system. The chart includes text labels such as "Machines," "Labels," "Storm drain water to stream," "Admin UI," "Analog/digital watermarking algorithm," "Data management API."

At the top right corner of the screenshot, there's a dropdown menu labeled 'Applications,' listing items like 'Blogs,' 'Digital enterprise strategy.,' 'Big data strategy.' The interface contains numerous options and sections within each category named, such as 'Analytics & dashboards,' 'Database operations,' 'Cloud infrastructure management.,' etc.

The bottom-right corner includes a user's personal workspace layout with icons representing different system elements. There appears to be an integrated storage system labeled 'HDFS,' and other icons for services like SQL Server, Jupyter Notebooks, Apache Kafka, and Amazon SageMaker.

The style of the image is reminiscent of a command dashboard for managing various software applications, showing both structured and possibly flowchart data elements as well as text descriptions labeling different elements within an IT infrastructure management interface.

figures.caption: Figure 2: LABIOS internal design.
figures.description:
The image displays a vertical, panoramic photograph that appears to be of a printed or digitally displayed document or map with multiple sections that are connected horizontally by dividers, each section containing a variety of text and graphics. Prominent on the left side are various rectangular shapes and icons in a vertical column that could represent components or parts within a system. Above this column, there is a title or heading that includes words like "DISTRIBUTION," "INTEGRATION," "PROCESSING," "OUTPUT," and other related terms.

Each section of the document shows different content:
- The leftmost section contains text with labels such as "ELECTRONIC DEVICE," "POWER SUPPLY," and illustrations that might depict these items or their parts.
- The middle sections feature more text, possibly explanatory notes, and small graphics that could be schematic diagrams or flowcharts, indicating different aspects of the system or product being described. These include symbols that appear to represent communication paths, data transfer, and other functional elements.
- The rightmost section shows the same pattern of labels, rectangles, text, and small icons as in the left side; this consistency suggests a repetitive structure across the document.

The color palette is limited, with a dominant use of neutral tones—grey, white, and muted colors—accentuated by black for the text. There's no strong contrast in terms of color between different sections or elements on the page, which blends the content together but does not make it visually engaging. The style of the image is graphic and utilitarian, suggesting a technical or informational nature to its content.

figures.caption: Figure 3: LABIOS deployment schemes.
figures.description:
The image depicts a detailed, hand-drawn flowchart with various colorful elements and annotations that appear to illustrate a complex system or process. The central theme of the flowchart is labeled "LABOS AS A STOREHOLDER OF RIO, QC AND MMS," which suggests it is related to laboratory operations in a retail or service setting.

At the top left corner, there's a text box with the heading "COMPTON SWITCH," containing elements that seem to represent network traffic or connections. From this point, multiple lines spread out across the flowchart, creating a somewhat chaotic pattern of interconnectivity. The lines are annotated with names of files, like "KITCOMB," "DATAFILES," and "LABOS SITE_UPLOAD," which could indicate the movement or transfer of data between different parts of the system.

At the bottom left, there is a section labeled "LUAGOS DATA STORAGE SERVER," connecting to other nodes across the diagram. Various icons are scattered throughout the diagram, such as computers represented by boxes with screens and keyboards, network switches indicated by circles, and a representation of a worker or employee labeled with the text "WORKER."

At one junction, lines point toward an arrow labeled "QC WERKS," branching out from the central flowchart. This suggests a quality control aspect to the overall system, possibly indicating where products or items are inspected before reaching the customers.

On the right side of the diagram, there is a section titled "STOREHOLDER'S BILL OF MATERIALS," which could represent inventory management and ordering processes within the system. The entire diagram seems to be attempting to visualize a comprehensive flow of information and processes in a lab-based environment with different roles and network components involved.

The art style is reminiscent of an unprofessional or schematic design, suggesting possible technical proficiency of the creator but a lack of artistic finesse in the drawing. The use of various colors and symbols indicates a focus on functionality over aesthetics. This flowchart serves as a visual document for comprehending the structure and workflow within a lab-based setting.

figures.caption: Figure 5: Anatomy of LABIOS operations.
figures.description:
This is a composite image consisting of five pie charts with overlay text and additional contextual information. Each chart features a different color representing a category: "Read" (red), "Write" (yellow), "Upload" (green), "Data Labeling" (black), and "Labels Worker" (blue). The pie charts appear to represent the percentage composition of various activities or actions related to the workflow of data processing.

The top left chart, labeled "Read," is color-coded with shades of red and states "READ: 14%." Adjacent to this chart, on the right side, there are three text boxes providing information about each pie chart segment. The text box for the red "Read" segment indicates "10 minutes spent reading published docs," with a link directing users to "Get data" and data labeling statistics.

The top right chart is labeled "Write" and shows percentages of data labeling activities (black) and writing (red). It describes "WRITE: 8%," "Time spent writing:" (with no specified timeframe), and a note that the process includes "Send docs to labels worker" with an associated link.

The bottom left pie chart is named "Upload" and illustrates "UPLOAD: 41%," without further details within its text boxes. Adjacent to this, on the right side, there's an additional text box labeled "UPDATE: 18%," again with a directive reading "Update docs in DB."

The bottom right pie chart is titled "DATA LABELING" and has percentages for "READ DATA: 92%" (black) and "LABEL WORKER: 8%." The description says, "TIME ELAPSED IN READING DATA/LABELING: 7 hours, with links provided to 'Get data' and 'Labels worker.'

In the center, there are statistics associated with each pie chart segment. For "Write," it states "Time spent updating docs in DB: 18%." The label on the pie chart indicates "WRITE: 14%" with a link directing to "Get data." For "DATA LABELING," it shows "READ DATA: 92%" without specific time data or links provided.

Overall, the image seems to be a dashboard or infographic summary of a workflow's efficiency and resource utilization in the context of data management and processing. The format of the image is informative, designed to convey metrics about productivity and project breakdown to viewers of the report.

figures.caption: Figure 6: LABIOS internal component evaluation.
figures.description:
The image is a multi-dimensional collage combining various graphs and text snippets related to COVID-19, specifically tracking the spread of the virus. At the top, we see three separate graphs:

1. The first graph has a pie chart on the upper left with different segments representing different countries where cases are reported, such as "Czechia", "India", and "USA". Each segment is color-coded to indicate the number of cases. 
2. A smaller set of bar charts appears to represent various parameters like population size, infections, death rates, etc., for regions such as Prague, London, Madrid, Berlin, and Mumbai. 
3. The third graph shows a line chart comparing the daily count of new COVID-19 cases for different countries, with a timestamp along the horizontal axis that seems to represent a time frame within which data is collected.

On the right side of the image, there are three additional graphs:

1. A spider pie chart represents various parameters like age groups, gender, and travel history, seemingly in relation to the virus spread.
2. A scatter plot with two axes shows different symbols for each case or occurrence, possibly indicating various variables related to the virus spread across multiple dimensions.
3. The top right section presents a map with several countries color-coded to reflect their COVID-19 status, with labels such as "Italy", "France", and "USA". Each country has a number indicator next to it. 

Text snippets are interspersed throughout the image. One prominent piece of text states, "13.4K people infected globally" beside a chart, suggesting the global reach of the virus at a particular point in time. Another snippet reads, "In total (95% CI)", possibly indicating a range or error margin for the data presented.

The overall style of the image is informational and utilitarian, with a clear focus on presenting and summarizing complex health-related information about the global reach and impact of COVID-19. The use of charts and maps suggests that this could be part of an analytical report or educational material on the subject.

The image is a screenshot of a digital chart, which appears to be part of a scientific study or research data presentation. It features a bar chart with multiple layers arranged both vertically and horizontally. Each layer has different types of data represented by lines, with varying lengths indicating numerical values.

At the top left corner, there's a title that is partially obscured; the visible portion reads "16000" suggesting it may be related to a specific unit or category of measurements. Next to this, there is smaller text describing a metric: "compute," with corresponding numbers: 120, 540, and in-between each number, a smaller numerical series decreases progressively from 75 to 5, labeled as "I.P." alongside the CPU processing time.

The first vertical axis on the left side lists different types of objects or entities that are being measured such as "client_processes," "server_processes," "#of_processes_total," and various numbers related to these processes. These entities are shown in a descending order based on their processing times, which increase from 106k at the bottom to over 9 million CPU cycles at the top.

The right side of the chart has additional blocks, each labeled with an entity like "java," "C++," and others. The numbers above these labels indicate the corresponding values in megabytes per second (MB/s). For example, "Java" is shown to consume 1636 MB/s, while "C++" takes up 524 MB/s.

The style of the image is clinical and appears to be a scientific or technical report with data visualization formatted using Microsoft Excel or a similar spreadsheet software. The exact nature of what is being measured and the significance of these values without context is not clear from the image alone.

The image appears to be a screenshot of a computer desktop with at least two open windows: one showing a bar graph and another showing a word cloud. The window on the left displays a bar chart with various activities performed against timestamps, such as '1049', 'write on FPMS@', '#2 75s' under a timestamp of '14:26' up to '1629', and 'Simplified the code' next to a timestamp of '18:57'. The bars represent different tasks or activities, each with a label and a numerical value beneath it.

The window on the right displays a word cloud with various terms like '#FPMS@', 'PFS', '#simulation', and other computer-related texts such as references to Python's virtual environment (virtualenv) and the command line (CLI). The words are arranged in clusters, with the most frequently used or prominent ones appearing larger.

Below the word cloud, there is a series of numbers that don't correspond to any visible context within the image: '1049', '#2 75s', and '#3 819', which might be related to commit messages in a Git repository or file system changes, indicating the process of committing files.

The text at the very top of the image seems to be related to performance metrics or statistics, possibly for software development: '2046,935,065,781,162,574,863': this might represent a sequence of numbers representing some kind of count or total, but without additional context, their exact meaning is unclear.

There's also a small image or icon in the bottom right corner, which appears to be a simplified diagrammatic sketch, but again, it lacks sufficient context within the image to determine its significance.

The image appears to be a graphical representation of some kind of data analysis, possibly from a medical field given the term "FSLABOS". Dominating the majority of the frame is a horizontal bar chart with several vertical lines in various colors, each representing different categories such as "Simulation", "Read", "Write", and some others whose names are not fully visible. The bars have numerical values on them, ranging from 0 to 1000 in increments of 100, suggesting a measure of frequency or intensity across these categories.

To the left of this bar chart, there's a smaller graph that includes both lines and dots, perhaps indicating different types of data (e.g., error rates or some form of measurements over time). The axes are labeled with "Time", "Simulation", and "Read", but the full text is not visible. This could be a timeline or some other form of temporal data.

In the top left corner, there's a bar-like structure that looks like it could be a progression diagram, possibly tracking 'Progression'. It includes stages marked from '0 to 1', but the full text is not legible due to resolution and size constraints.

The overall style of the image suggests it's a screenshot of a scientific or technical presentation, potentially from a software application used for data analysis or experimentation setup. There is no visible company name or manufacturer logo among the texts present in the image, nor are there any logos that immediately reveal the nature of the software or hardware being referenced. The overall layout and design suggest an academic or professional context, most likely within the realm of engineering, biology, or a similar data-driven field.

The image you're referring to is a gray-toned graphical representation of data, which appears to be from a scientific study or technical presentation. This type of display is often used in fields like machine learning or cybersecurity to convey statistical metrics or performance results.

On the left side of the chart, there's a series of bar graphs with different labels such as "map", "reduce", "local", and other technical terms that are typical in programming language and algorithmic functions. These bars display values in thousands, ranging from 980 to 3670, which could represent some form of compute metric or similar.

In the center, there's a line graph with a title that reads "overall time". This graph shows two y-axes and plots points with different y-values across an x-axis, indicating some fluctuating variable over time. The x-axis is labeled 'x', where each point represents data collected at regular intervals during some study or experiment.

On the right side of the chart, there's another line graph plotting data from 'x to x374', with a title 'CPU time'. This graph also has two y-axes, one for CPU time in seconds and the other for the memory load, both ranging between 0 and 1023. The bars at the bottom represent different compute resources used throughout an experiment or dataset: "lab", "hashmap", "disk", and "local", which are commonly involved in computational processes.

In terms of visual information, the colors within the plots don't have visible labels or a legend for identification. The purpose of this data seems to be quantifying the performance or resource usage over time across different tasks or operations, such as map, reduce, and local functions, within an algorithmic context that could involve machine learning or large-scale distributed computing.
